abstract.text: We describe the application of a new QSAR (quantitative structure-activity relationship) formalism to the analysis and modeling of PDE-4 inhibitors.
This new method takes advantage of the X-ray structural information of the PDE-4 enzyme to characterize the small molecule inhibitors.
It calculates molecular descriptors based on the matching of their pharmacophore feature pairs with those (the reference) of the target binding pocket.
Since the reference is derived from the X-ray crystal structures of the target under study, these descriptors are target-specific and easy to interpret.
We have analyzed 35 indole derivative-based PDE-4 inhibitors where Partial Least Square (PLS) analysis has been employed to obtain the predictive models.
Compared to traditional QSAR methods such as CoMFA and CoMSIA, our models are more robust and predictive measured by statistics for both the training and test sets of molecules.
Our method can also identify critical pharmacophore features that are responsible for the inhibitory potency of the small molecules.
Thus, this structure-based QSAR method affords both descriptive and predictive models for phosphodiesterase-4 inhibitors.

The success of this study has also laid a solid foundation for systematic QSAR modeling of the PDE family of enzymes, which will ultimately contribute to chemical genomics research and drug discovery targeting the PDE enzymes.

The cyclic nucleotide phosphodiesterases (or PDE's) comprise a group of enzymes that degrade the phosphodiester bond in the second messenger molecules cAMP and cGMP.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: They regulate the localization, duration, and amplitude of cyclic nucleotide signaling within subcellular domains.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Thus, PDE's are important regulators of signal transduction mediated by these second messenger molecules [1][2][3].
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: According to their sequence homology, substrate specificity and pharmacological properties, the PDE enzymes are classified into 11 families (i.e., PDE1 -PDE11) [2].
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Even though different subtypes of this super-family are functionally related, they do have different substrate specificities.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: For example, PDE-4, PDE-7 and PDE-8 are cAMP selective, whereas PDE-5, PDE-6 and PDE-9 are cGMP selective.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Other members of this family (e.g., PDE-1, PDE-2, PDE-3, PDE-10 and PDE-11) can hydrolyse both cAMP and cGMP.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Phosphodiesterases have proven to be a therapeutically important class of drug targets.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Sildenafil is an inhibitor of cGMP-specific phosphodiesterase (PDE-5) and used to treat erectile dysfunction (ED) [4].
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Inhibitors of PDE-4 have been explored as potential drugs for chronic obstructive pulmonary disorder (COPD) [5].
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Inhibitors of other PDE enzymes are being explored for coronary heart disease [6], dementia, depression, and schizophrenia [7].
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Thus, there are continuing interests in discovering novel inhibitors of PDE enzymes that are potent and selective for specific subtypes.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: We have been interested in modeling the inhibitors of PDE-4 due to their potential in treating neurodegenerative diseases and cognitive disorders.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: PDE-4 selectively hydrolyzes cAMP and has been mostly targeted for the treatment of inflammation, and in particular chronic obstructive pulmonary disorder (COPD) [5].
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: However, selective phosphodiesterase-4 (PDE-4) inhibitors have been demonstrated recently as novel agents to treat memory deficit [8] and neurodegeneration [9].
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Preclinical studies indicate that these PDE-4 inhibitors can counteract deficits in long-term memory caused by pharmacological agents, aging or overexpression of mutant forms of human amyloid precursor proteins [9].
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Although a number of major advances have been made with respect to PDE-4 inhibition, most of the PDE-4 inhibitors have unacceptable side effects, particularly nausea and emesis [10,11].
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Thus, it is critically important to understand the structural determinants of potent and selective PDE-4 inhibitors, so that we can rationally design new molecules that minimize the undesirable side effects.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Most PDE-4 inhibitors can be classified into three structural families: rolipram-related compounds, xanthine derivatives and nitraquazone analogues [12].
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: This structural diversity suggests that the binding site of the PDE-4 enzyme presents a number of alternative pharmacophores that are capable of interacting with different classes of small molecule inhibitors.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Many investigators have tried to understand the structural basis for PDE-4 inhibition (both potency and selectivity) by constructing 3D QSAR (quantitative structureactivity relationship) models based on known PDE-4 inhibitors [12][13][14][15][16].
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Even though these models provided preliminary pharmacophoric insights into PDE-4 inhibitors, the absence of the 3D structure of the target enzyme (i.e., PDE-4) in these models poses a major limitation on the reliability and interpretability of these models.

body_text.text: METHODS AND MATERIALS
Dataset
35 indole derivative-based PDE-4 inhibitors [15] were used in this study.
body_text.section: Dataset

body_text.text: The molecular structures and their biological activities against PDE-4 are given in Table 1.
body_text.section: Dataset

body_text.text: The compounds contain an indole moiety which replaces the "rolipram-like" 3-methoxy-4-cyclopentoxy motif.
body_text.section: Dataset

body_text.text: The activities were determined from measurement of serum TNFlevels in LPS challenged mice (mouse endotoxemia model) [24].
body_text.section: Dataset

body_text.text: This dataset covers a variety of molecules with various levels of inhibitory activities against PDE-4.
body_text.section: Dataset

body_text.text: Fig. (1) shows the activity distribution of the 35 indole derivatives.
body_text.section: Dataset

body_text.text: To develop and rigorously validate a QSAR model, 28 molecules were selected as the training set, and the remaining 7 molecules were held out as the test set.
body_text.section: Dataset

body_text.text: The specific selection of the training and test sets was determined by either randomly splitting or clustering-based splitting of the original dataset.The 3D conformations of all the inhibitors were generated using the OMEGA 2.0 program available from OpenEye Scientific (OMEGA 2.0, OE Scientific, NM, USA).
body_text.section: Dataset

body_text.text: In this study, only the best conformer of each molecule was used to generate the pharmacophore points.

body_text.text: The Overall Work Flow of the QSAR Method
Deriving Pharmacophore Feature Pairs from Ligand-Receptor (R-L) Complex
The LigandScout program [25] was first employed to derive structure-based pharmacophore centers (Fig. 3a).
body_text.section: Deriving Pharmacophore Feature Pairs from Ligand-Receptor (R-L) Complex

body_text.text: The advanced 3D pharmacophore model option of the Ligand-Scout program was used, which allows multiple pharmacophore feature types on the same heavy atom.
body_text.section: Deriving Pharmacophore Feature Pairs from Ligand-Receptor (R-L) Complex

body_text.text: The pharmacophore feature types used in this study include hydrogen bond donor (D), hydrogen bond acceptor (A), positively charged (P), negatively charged (N), and lipophilic (L) centers.
body_text.section: Deriving Pharmacophore Feature Pairs from Ligand-Receptor (R-L) Complex

body_text.text: Pharmacophore feature pairs are then generated by making all possible pair-wise combinations of the above pharmacophore centers.
body_text.section: Deriving Pharmacophore Feature Pairs from Ligand-Receptor (R-L) Complex

body_text.text: A specific pharmacophore feature pair is determined by both the feature types involved and the distance between the two centers.
body_text.section: Deriving Pharmacophore Feature Pairs from Ligand-Receptor (R-L) Complex

body_text.text: For example, AL in Fig. (3a) indicates a hydrogen bond acceptor (A) and lipophilic (L) feature pair; and the distance between them is 4.5 .
body_text.section: Deriving Pharmacophore Feature Pairs from Ligand-Receptor (R-L) Complex

body_text.text: Another example, AP, means a hydrogen bond acceptor (A) and a positive (P) feature pair and their inter-feature distance is 3.8
body_text.section: Deriving Pharmacophore Feature Pairs from Ligand-Receptor (R-L) Complex

body_text.text: . All possible feature pairs are generated, and this recorded information reflects the pharmacophoric characteristics of the target binding site, and will be used as the reference for generating the SB-PPK descriptors of the inhibitor molecules. To avoid confusion with traditional pharmacophore fingerprints, we note that we do not need "distance binning" to capture different possible distance ranges because the pharmacophore features pairs are derived from the 3D structure of the target protein. Thus, all the feature pairs have defined distances.
body_text.section: Deriving Pharmacophore Feature Pairs from Ligand-Receptor (R-L) Complex

The LigandScout program [25] is used to perceive the pharmacophoric groups on small organic molecules (Fig.  3b).
body_text.section: Perception of Pharmacophore Feature Pairs for a Ligand

body_text.text: All pair-wise combinations of the perceived pharmacophore centers are checked for the feature types and interfeature distances.
body_text.section: Perception of Pharmacophore Feature Pairs for a Ligand

body_text.text: In the example given in Fig. (3b), there is an AL pair and an AP pair, and the inter-feature distances for each pair are 4.6 A and 3.8 A, respectively.

Once the pharmacophore feature pairs for both the receptor and ligand molecules are generated, we can compare them to determine pattern matches.
body_text.section: Generation of Structure-Based Pharmacophore Key (SB-PPK) Descriptors

body_text.text: For example, Fig. (3c) shows that AL's and AP's from the receptor's pharmacophore feature pairs (the reference) and small molecule's pharmacophore pairs match with each other.

body_text.text: Statistical Analysis with Partial Least Square (PLS) Method
The relationship between the molecular descriptors and the biological activities is modeled by the PLS (Partial Least Square) method [26].
body_text.section: Statistical Analysis with Partial Least Square (PLS) Method

body_text.text: Specifically, the PLS implementation in the MOE package (Chemical Computing Group, Montreal, Canada) was used in this study.
body_text.section: Statistical Analysis with Partial Least Square (PLS) Method

body_text.text: Other types of machine learning methods can be used as well to analyze the dataset.

body_text.text: Validation of the QSAR Models
Model validation is a critical step in any QSAR study.
body_text.section: Validation of the QSAR Models

body_text.text: As shown in Fig. (4), we have adopted a standard workflow, similar to what Tropsha group advocate [23], to build robustly predictive QSAR models.
body_text.section: Validation of the QSAR Models

body_text.text: Rational splitting of the dataset into training and test sets as well as obtaining the statistics for both the training set and test sets is critical in this model validation protocol.
body_text.section: Validation of the QSAR Models

body_text.text: Thus, a given dataset is split into multiple pairs of training and test sets.
body_text.section: Validation of the QSAR Models

body_text.text: Both random shuffling and clustering-based [27] splitting of the data set can be used for dataset partitioning.
body_text.section: Validation of the QSAR Models

body_text.text: In the random shuffling approach, the first 7 molecules were held out as the test set after the order of molecules in the data set was randomly shuffled.
body_text.section: Validation of the QSAR Models

body_text.text: In the clustering-based partitioning approach, the dataset was split in such a way that both the training set (28 molecules) and the test set (7 molecules) had the most coverage of the clusters.
body_text.section: Validation of the QSAR Models

body_text.text: For each split, PLS was used to analyze the training set in order to build a PLS regression model.
body_text.section: Validation of the QSAR Models

body_text.text: Regression coeffi-cients were then calculated for both the training set (r 2 ) and the test set (R 2 ).
body_text.section: Validation of the QSAR Models

body_text.text: While the former reflects the model quality as measured on the training set, the latter (R 2 ) is a more robust indicator of the predictive power of the model.
body_text.section: Validation of the QSAR Models

body_text.text: In the end, only those model(s) with both coefficients greater than set thresholds are retained as the final model(s).
body_text.section: Validation of the QSAR Models

body_text.text: RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
Pharmacophore Features of the PDE-4 Binding Site

As described before (Cf. Method), LigandScout was used to analyze the interactions between PDE-4 inhibitors and the binding site of PDE-4, based on the X-ray structure of the inhibitor-bound PDE-4 (1xon.pdb).
body_text.section: Pharmacophore Features of the PDE-4 Binding Site

body_text.text: This analysis has revealed nine pharmacophore centers.
body_text.section: Pharmacophore Features of the PDE-4 Binding Site

body_text.text: The 3D rendering and the 2D depiction of the interactions are shown in Fig. (5a) and Fig. (5b), respectively.
body_text.section: Pharmacophore Features of the PDE-4 Binding Site

body_text.text: The following occupies the four hydrophobic centers: the cyclopentane ring, two chlorine atoms on the pyridine ring, and the central benzene ring.
body_text.section: Pharmacophore Features of the PDE-4 Binding Site

body_text.text: The cyclopentane ring interacts with hydrophobic residues in the PDE-4 binding pocket: MET337, MET357, PHE340, PHE372, and ILE336.
body_text.section: Pharmacophore Features of the PDE-4 Binding Site

body_text.text: Chlorines on the pyridine ring interact with hydrophobic residues MET273, PHE340, ILE336, and LEU319, and the central benzene ring interacts with ILE336, PHE372 and TYR159.
body_text.section: Pharmacophore Features of the PDE-4 Binding Site

body_text.text: The amide nitrogen occupies a hydrogen bond donor center, which interacts with a water molecule that serves as a bridge to the enzyme's binding pocket.
body_text.section: Pharmacophore Features of the PDE-4 Binding Site

body_text.text: Four hydrogen bond acceptor centers are identified and they are occupied by the following atoms/groups: the methoxy oxygen on the benzene ring, amide oxygen, pyridine nitrogen, and the ether oxygen (connecting the benzene and the cyclopentane rings).
body_text.section: Pharmacophore Features of the PDE-4 Binding Site

body_text.text: The methoxy oxygen and the ether oxygen atoms both interact with GLN369.
body_text.section: Pharmacophore Features of the PDE-4 Binding Site

body_text.text: The amide oxygen and the pyridine nitrogen interact with the small molecule EDO744 and a water molecule, respectively.
body_text.section: Pharmacophore Features of the PDE-4 Binding Site

body_text.text: Effect of Dataset Partitioning on QSAR Model Quality
To build high quality, predictive QSAR models, we systematically performed dataset splitting into training and test sets using both random shuffling and clustering-based splitting methods.
body_text.section: Effect of Dataset Partitioning on QSAR Model Quality

body_text.text: For each partitioning approach, we obtained ten different training/test sets, and built 90 different QSAR models with the number of principal components ranging from 2 to 10.
body_text.section: Effect of Dataset Partitioning on QSAR Model Quality

body_text.text: Of all 180 QSAR models, the conventional correlation coefficient r 2 ranges from 0.69 to 0.89, and the predictive R 2 values range from 0.05 to 0.75.
body_text.section: Effect of Dataset Partitioning on QSAR Model Quality

body_text.text: The splitting which renders the highest r 2 and R 2 for corresponding models with number of principle components between 5 and 8 is selected as the partitioning of training and test sets to build the final QSAR models.

body_text.text: CONCLUSIONS
We have successfully applied a new structure-based QSAR formalism to study the SAR (Structure-activity Relationship) of 35 PDE-4 inhibitors.
body_text.section: CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: This new QSAR formalism describes molecular structures based on the matching of their pharmacophore feature pairs with those (the reference) of the target binding pocket.
body_text.section: CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: This reference is derived from the Xray crystal structures of the target under study.
body_text.section: CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: Thus, these descriptors are target-specific and easy to interpret.
body_text.section: CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: The PLS (partial least square) method is then employed to reveal the correlation between these target-specific descriptors and the biological activity, and help identify the critical pharmacophore features for PDE-4 inhibition.
body_text.section: CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: To ensure the predictive ability of the built QSAR models, we have adopted a rigorous model validation protocol that emphasizes rational design of the training and test sets, and uses the statistics calculated for both the training set (r 2 ) and test set (R 2 ) as the model selection criteria.
body_text.section: CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: Consequently, our models display highly balanced predictive ability for both the training and the test sets ( Table 3).
body_text.section: CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: In contrast, CoMFA and CoMSIA models have shown signs of over fitting, with high r 2 for the training set but much lower R 2 for the test set.
body_text.section: CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: Thus, this model validation protocol based on both training and test set statistics is critical for the success of this study.
body_text.section: CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: The new structure-based descriptors overcome the drawbacks of traditional descriptors that ignore the binding pocket information.
body_text.section: CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: These target-specific descriptors could offer structural insights into the critical features responsible for the potency of the inhibitors.
body_text.section: CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: The feature importance analysis proposed in this study has helped fulfill this task.
body_text.section: CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: Thus, our models afford both predictive and descriptive models for PDE-4 inhibitors.
body_text.section: CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: Since the structures of many other PDE enzymes have also been solved (e.g., PDE5: 2h44, 2h42, 2h40; PDE-9: 2hd1; PDE3B: 1soj, 1so2; PDE2A: 1z1l and PDE1B: 1taz), the success of this study has also laid a solid foundation for studying the inhibition mechanisms of other PDE enzymes using this new structure-based QSAR formalism.
body_text.section: CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: Such a systematic study of the whole family of PDE enzymes will eventually afford insights into the structural requirements for both the potency and selectivity of PDE inhibition, and ultimately contributes to chemical genomics research and therapeutic development targeting the PDE family of enzymes.
